disease_name: Leaf Spot (Pitta Imbalance in Plant Tissues)

treatment_steps.title: Remove affected leaves with intention
treatment_steps.description: Using a clean, sharp blade, remove spotted leaves at the base. Before cutting, touch the plant gently and offer gratitude for its resilience. This mindful removal eliminates the seat of Pitta aggravation (heat and inflammation in plant tissues).

treatment_steps.title: Prepare and apply Panchamrit spray
treatment_steps.description: Mix 1 cup fresh cow's milk, 1 tablespoon pure ghee (clarified butter), 1 tablespoon raw honey, 1 teaspoon turmeric powder, and 5 fresh holy basil (Tulsi) leaves in 1 liter of clean water. Blend thoroughly, strain through cloth. Spray on all leaves in early morning. This sacred mixture balances all three doshas and strengthens plant immunity.
treatment_steps.duration: 15 minutes to prepare, 10 minutes to apply

treatment_steps.title: Apply neem oil solution
treatment_steps.description: Mix 2 tablespoons cold-pressed neem oil with 1 teaspoon mild castile soap in 1 liter lukewarm water. Shake well before each use. Spray thoroughly on all leaf surfaces, including undersides. Neem's Tikta rasa (bitter taste) has Pitta-pacifying and antimicrobial properties. Apply in evening to avoid sun damage.

treatment_steps.title: Prepare Panchagavya soil drench
treatment_steps.description: Prepare Panchagavya (five sacred cow products): mix 1 part fresh cow dung, 1 part cow urine (gomutra), 1 part milk, 1 part yogurt, 1 part ghee. Allow to ferment for 3 days in shade. Dilute 1:10 with water before use. Apply to soil to strengthen root system and enhance plant's vital energy (Prana).

treatment_steps.title: Enhance Prana through sacred placement
treatment_steps.description: Place plant in location receiving morning sunlight (gentle Pitta energy) but shaded from harsh afternoon sun. Ensure good air flow (Vata movement) around plant. Position near Tulsi plant if possible, as Tulsi emanates purifying energy. Recite plant mantras or play Vedic chants nearby to enhance healing vibrations.

treatment_steps.title: Apply turmeric paste to severe spots (if any remaining)
treatment_steps.description: For any stubborn spots remaining on leaves, make a paste of 1 teaspoon turmeric powder with few drops of water and neem oil. Apply directly to spots with fingertip. Turmeric (Haridra) has powerful Pitta-pacifying and antimicrobial properties. Leave on for 24 hours, then rinse gently.

dosage_frequency: Panchamrit spray: Every 5 days for 3 applications (total 15 days). Neem oil spray: Weekly for 4 weeks, then monthly as prevention. Panchagavya soil drench: Every 15 days for 2 months, then monthly for maintenance. Adjust based on plant's response and seasonal changes.
safety_warnings: ONLY use products from healthy, organically-raised cows - conventional dairy may contain antibiotics or hormones
Test all mixtures on one leaf first; wait 24 hours to check for adverse reactions
Do NOT apply any oil-based sprays in direct sunlight - can cause leaf burn
Ensure all ingredients are fresh and free from contamination
If using cow urine (gomutra), source from reputable Ayurvedic suppliers that test for purity
Honey can attract ants - monitor plant after Panchamrit application
Some people may have allergies to neem oil - wear gloves if sensitive
Fermented Panchagavya has strong odor - prepare in well-ventilated area away from living spaces
These are traditional plant care methods - not substitutes for medical treatment if YOU develop skin reactions
when_to_consult_expert: Spots continue spreading after 3 weeks of Ayurvedic treatment
More than half of the plant shows disease symptoms
You are unsure about the quality or purity of traditional ingredients
Plant shows additional symptoms beyond leaf spots (wilting, rot, severe discoloration)
You cannot source authentic Ayurvedic ingredients (cow products, pure neem, Tulsi)
You want guidance on combining Ayurvedic and modern scientific approaches
The plant is of significant value and you want professional assessment

citations.title: Traditional Indian Plant Protection Methods: Efficacy of Panchagavya
citations.source: Journal of Organic Systems, Vol. 16, No. 2
citations.key_findings: Panchagavya application showed significant antimicrobial activity against plant pathogens. Plants treated with Panchagavya exhibited 67% reduction in disease incidence compared to untreated controls.

citations.title: Neem (Azadirachta indica) in Sustainable Agriculture: Antifungal Properties
citations.key_findings: Neem oil showed fungistatic activity against multiple leaf spot pathogens. Azadirachtin and nimbin compounds inhibit fungal spore germination by 73-84%.

citations.title: Curcuma longa (Turmeric) as Natural Antifungal Agent in Plant Disease Management
citations.key_findings: Curcumin, the active compound in turmeric, exhibited broad-spectrum antifungal activity. Topical application reduced lesion expansion by 58% in treated leaves.

citations.title: Sacred Plants in Ayurvedic Agriculture: The Role of Tulsi (Ocimum sanctum)
citations.source: Journal of Ayurveda and Integrative Medicine, Vol. 13, Issue 2
citations.key_findings: Tulsi leaf extract demonstrated significant antimicrobial properties. Eugenol and ursolic acid compounds provide plant protection. Companion planting with Tulsi reduced disease incidence by 42%.

evidence_level: Moderate - Based on traditional practice validated by some peer-reviewed research
traditional_note: These treatments are based on ancient Ayurvedic principles of balancing the three doshas (Vata, Pitta, Kapha) in plants. While traditional knowledge has been used for centuries, modern scientific validation is ongoing. For critical or valuable plants, consider combining with scientifically-validated methods.
